Key Match Events: Wiese and Gerhard Erasmus took advantage of Bilal Khan's pace, hitting four boundaries to score 21 runs for Namibia in the Super Over.
Wiese scored 13 runs off four balls with the bat in the first super over, then bowled brilliantly, limiting Oman to only ten runs to win.
Post-Match Reflections: Wiese stated that he 'aged a couple of years' older and that the evening had been emotionally draining.
Wiese said that the pitch was two-paced, requiring a batter to take some time before going crazy over bowlers.
Wiese was disheartened that his team allowed Oman to come back into the game after dismissing them for a low target.

Wiese said, 'Difficult to gauge a good target because if you're chasing 180 then you're playing differently. But when you let them bowl the way they did, you bring them back into the game. Lots of learnings from this game.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: The match at Kensington Oval went to a super over following a nail-biting low-scoring duel in which Oman was swept out for 109 runs.
Namibia's run chase then stuttered as Oman's Mehran Khan's outstanding bowling effort saw them finish on 109-6, setting up the Super Over drama.
The game finished in a tie, marking the first Super Over in a men's T20 World Cup tournament since 2012.
Wiese was given the Player of the Match award for his outstanding performance as an all-rounder.
Others: The all-rounder demonstrated composure under pressure, securing a remarkable win that showcased the drama and excitement of T20 cricket on the world stage.
Wiese emerged as the hero for Namibia with both bat and ball as he slammed 13 in the Super Over and came back to bowl, got a wicket, defending 21 runs.
